item.title: Why Iranians Are Protesting Once Again
item.description: Amid growing repression, a sickly economy and bleak prospects, the death of one young woman was all it took.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: Iran Protests Surge to Dozens of Cities
item.description: Iranians fed up with oppressive rules and a battered economy have faced bullets, tear gas and arrests to demand an end to the Islamic Republic’s rule.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators on the streets of Tehran this past week. Protests spurred by a woman’s death in custody have expanded to include outrage over economic problems and frustration with moral strictures.

item.title: They Were Entitled to Free Care. Hospitals Hounded Them to Pay.
item.description: With the help of a consulting firm, the Providence hospital system trained staff to wring money out of patients, even those eligible for free care.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mel Haasch; Photographs by Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times

item.title: How a Hospital Chain Used a Poor Neighborhood to Turn Huge Profits
item.description: Bon Secours Mercy Health, a major nonprofit health system, used the poverty of Richmond Community Hospital’s patients to tap into a lucrative federal drug program.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mel Haasch; Photograph by Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times

item.title: In Ukraine’s South, Fierce Fighting and Deadly Costs
item.description: The offensive in the south was the most highly anticipated military action of the summer. Ukraine is making gains, but the fighting is grinding, grueling and steep in casualties.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at an entrenched position this month near the Kherson front.

item.title: For Suburban Texas Men, a Workout Craze With a Side of Faith
item.description: In Katy, outside Houston, many men have taken up F3, a no-frills fitness group where members push themselves physically but also bond emotionally.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham and Meridith Kohut
item.media:description: About 30 men praying together after an F3 workout at Katy City Park in Katy, Texas. Although F3 is ostensibly nonsectarian, many groups have a Christian emphasis.

item.title: The New India: Expanding Influence Abroad, Straining Democracy at Home
item.description: As India rises, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has faced little pushback as he weaponizes institutions to consolidate power and entrench his Hindu nationalist vision.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergei Bobylev/Sputnik, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting in Uzbekistan this month.

item.title: Puerto Ricans Fear Extended Blackout After Hurricane Fiona
item.description: Residents, who pay some of the highest electricity rates in the United States, say they have little patience for the kind of outages they faced after Hurricane Maria.
item.dc:creator: Laura N. Pérez Sánchez
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dennis Rodríguez’s home, in the center of San Juan, has been without power since Hurricane Fiona hit Puerto Rico last week.

item.title: LinkedIn Ran Social Experiments on 20 Million Users Over Five Years
item.description: A study that looked back at those tests found that relatively weak social connections were more helpful in finding jobs than stronger social ties.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Sundry Photography/Alamy
item.media:description: Researchers examined changes that LinkedIn had made to its “People You May Know” algorithm to test what sociologists call the “strength of weak ties.”

item.title: ‘Ours’ Makes Couples Counseling More Accessible. Does It Work?
item.description: Two survivors of pandemic parenting needed a relationship tuneup. Could a new virtual therapy module called Ours do the trick?
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seligson
item.media:credit: Jeanette Spicer for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author and her husband, Andrew, at work on their marriage.

item.title: In Washington State, the Midterm Race Between Joe Kent and Marie Gluesenkamp Perez Has It All
item.description: This congressional race in Washington State shows the November elections in microcosm.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times

item.title: Putin and Trump, the Solo Soulless Saboteurs
item.description: Putin and Trump, dragging the world down with them.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yury Kochetkov

item.title: This Threat to Democracy Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: Trump and his allies are trying to take over the machinery of American elections.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photograph by Stephen Maturen, via Getty Images

item.title: What Putin’s Nuclear Threat Means for Ukraine and the U.S.
item.description: Russia is flailing and losing. The nuclear threat is growing.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Let’s Talk About the Economic Roots of White Supremacy
item.description: It’s not just about racism.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Bettmann/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Dixiecrats: College students at the 1948 Southern Democratic Convention.

item.title: Since You’ve Been Gone: What’s Next for the Royal Corgis?
item.description: Considering the future of the short yet noble canines.
item.dc:creator: Emily Flake
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: How Do You Handle a Wounded Putin?
item.description: You push him back in Ukraine, but slowly.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski/Agence France-Presse—Getty Images

item.title: What Issue Is Most On Your Mind for the Midterm Elections?
item.description: We want to know what’s motivating your vote ahead of Election Day.
item.dc:creator: New York Times Opinion
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: For Churches, Abortion Politics Is a Double-Edged Sword
item.description: Ireland and Poland went in entirely opposite directions on abortion. Why?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters celebrate at Dublin Castle after a constitutional amendment legalizing abortion passed in 2018.

item.title: Popcast Live! The New Faces of 2022
item.description: Blondshell, Central Cee, Ethel Cain and more: a conversation about what’s breaking through, plus questions from the audience at our first live taping.
item.media:credit: Irina Rozovsky for The New York Times

item.title: A Year When Everything Is Going Right for Western Canada’s Farmers
item.description: This year’s harvest will be bountiful, with prices more than offsetting increased costs for items like fuel.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Canada’s farmers are expected to harvest near-record yields this year.

item.title: Louise Fletcher, 88, Dies; Oscar Winner for ‘One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest’
item.description: She was largely unknown to the public when she was cast as what the American Film Institute called one of cinema’s most memorable villains.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.category: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (Book)
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Louise Fletcher in 1976, when she won an Academy Award for her performance in “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.”

item.title: Dragon Fruit Is Showing Up All Over. So Why Are Farmers Leaving the Business?
item.description: The flavor is a fixture on drink menus. But competition from abroad has South Florida growers rethinking their commitment to a once-lucrative crop that requires a lot of investment and care.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times

item.title: Fiona Hits Parts of Canada With Flooding, Power Failures and Destruction
item.description: Forecasters described Fiona as “a historic storm” that slammed eastern Canada on Saturday. At least one person was missing after being swept out to sea, the police said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Michael King/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Fiona flooded the Burnt Islands on the southwestern coast of Newfoundland, Canada.

item.title: Tasmania Races to Save Pilot Whales After Hundreds Are Stranded
item.description: After 230 pilot whales were stranded on the western coast of Tasmania, a scramble started almost immediately to save as many as possible.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Matthew Newton for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Hocking, center, and other scientists from Tasmanian Museum on Friday examined pilot whales that died after they stranded on a beach along the western coast of Tasmania, Australia.

item.title: Is Natural Wine Actually Better for You?
item.description: Fewer headaches. Less severe hangovers. Better gut health. How do these health claims stack up against the science?
item.dc:creator: Jesse Hirsch
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: When Should I Get the New Bivalent Booster?
item.description: You are allowed to get the shot two months after a previous dose, but some experts suggest waiting a little longer.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times

item.title: How to Exercise Safely Outside in the Fall and Winter
item.description: Here are a few ways to protect yourself from the elements, oncoming traffic and other threats that ramp up in the fall and winter months.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: ‘Preventative’ Botox: Do Injections Work to Reduce Wrinkles?
item.description: Or are injections just a temporary, addictive fix?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Fentanyl and Why It’s So Dangerous
item.description: Drug overdoses have reached record highs. Experts offer tips to talk about opioids with your family.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega, Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: How a Sooty Old Piano Helped Beth Orton Reach a New Creative Peak
item.description: With a vintage upright and painstakingly assembled songs, the English folk-pop-electronic songwriter’s eighth studio album, “Weather Alive,” is her best.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Rosie Marks for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I was like, ‘OK, I don’t know how to play this instrument, but wow, it just sounds so beautiful,’” Orton said of her piano.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
